Rapid landslide detection technologies are crucial for informing emergency responses. Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) is a remote sensing technique that can provide measurements of affected areas regardless of weather or lighting conditions. However, the usage of SAR is hindered by the need for domain knowledge in pre-processing steps and expert interpretation. We provide simplified, pre-processed, machine-learning ready SAR datacubes for four globally located landslide events obtained from Sentinel-1 satellite passes before and after a landslide triggering event, along with segmentation maps of the landslides.

Using the Hokkaido, Japan datacube, we investigate the feasibility of SAR-based landslide detection with supervised deep learning (DL). Our results demonstrate that DL models can be used to detect landslides from SAR data, achieving an Area under the Precision-Recall curve exceeding 0.7. We find that additional satellite visits enhance detection performance, but that early detection is possible when SAR data is combined with terrain information from a digital elevation model. This can be particularly useful for time-critical emergency interventions.

Code is made publicly available at https://github.com/iprapas/landslide-sar-unet.

According to the United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction, landslides have affected 4.8 million people and caused 18,414 deaths between 1998-2017. Rising temperatures and climate change are projected to worsen this situation, with an increase in sustained droughts and intense rainfall events. Given these predictions, there is a growing need for timely and accurate landslide assessment methods that can inform decision-makers and emergency responders.

In the aftermath of a landslide, optical satellite imagery is commonly used to map the extent of the event. However, optical data is often hindered by clouds and limited to daytime observations, motivating the study of weather-independent Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) as a monitoring technique. DL algorithms for computer vision can be used for SAR analysis if SAR data is represented as images or georeferenced data arrays.

The landslide change detection with DL can be performed in two ways: object-level and pixel-level detection. Previous studies have used bi- and tri-temporal images for landslide mapping using DL and SAR images. The usage of multi-temporal SAR polarization modes has been demonstrated with traditional approaches, such as thresholding, and similar conclusions have been reported in DL studies. However, these methods require longer time series of SAR data, which are unavailable in an emergency scenario.

To overcome this barrier, we publicly release curated DL-ready datasets that include SAR intensity and interferometry data before and after disaster events that triggered landslides. Using part of this dataset, we develop a supervised DL algorithm for landslide detection and demonstrate the feasibility of rapid detection using only one satellite pass, if SAR data is combined with terrain information.

We produce analysis-ready datacubes with multiple layers of SAR time-series data and auxiliary geographic information for multiple landslide events. To this end, we develop a data pipeline that processes SAR intensity and interferometric products from multiple sources and compiles them with a Digital Elevation Model (DEM) and DEM-derived products into a format that can be fed into DL models (see Fig. 1).

In this study, we focus our machine learning experiments on the datacube created for earthquake-triggered landslides over Hokkaido, Japan in 2017 (Fig. 2). Additional datacubes are available for landslide events over Mt. Talak.
